action.action-desc: Mr. Higgins of Louisiana (for himself and Mr. Donalds) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Oversight and Government Reform

form.official-title: To establish standards for law enforcement officers in the District of Columbia to engage in vehicular pursuits of suspects, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the District of Columbia Policing Protection Act.

section.header: Vehicular pursuits by law enforcement officers in District of Columbia

subsection.text: The Comprehensive Policing and Justice Reform Amendment Act of 2022 (D.C. Law 24–345) is amended—

paragraph.text: in subtitle S of title I—

subparagraph.text: in the heading, by striking LIMITATIONS ON THE;

clause.text: by redesignating paragraphs (6) and (7) as paragraphs (1) and (2), respectively;
by redesignating paragraph (12) as paragraph (3); and

subparagraph.text: in section 128 (sec. 5–365.02, D.C. Official Code), by striking subsections (a), (b), and (c) and inserting the following:

section.text: If a law enforcement officer encounters a suspect fleeing in a motor vehicle, the officer shall engage in a vehicular pursuit of the suspect unless the officer, or a higher-ranking official with supervisory authority over the officer, reasonably believes that—

subparagraph.text: entail an unacceptable risk of harm to a person other than the suspect; or

paragraph.text: the suspect can be apprehended more effectively or expeditiously by a means other than vehicular pursuit.
in the table of contents, by striking the item relating to subtitle S of title I and inserting the following:

multi-column-toc-entry.level-header: USE OF VEHICULAR PURSUITS BY LAW ENFORCEMENT OFFICERS

subsection.header: Department of Justice report on PursuitAlert
subsection.text: Not later than 3 years after the date of enactment of this Act, the Attorney General shall—

paragraph.text: evaluate the costs and benefits of the Metropolitan Police Department of the District of Columbia adopting PursuitAlert or another similar technology capable of alerting members of the public to the presence of a police pursuit in their immediate vicinity; and
publish a report on the evaluation conducted under paragraph (1) and submit the report to—

subparagraph.text: the Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs of the Senate;
the Committee on the Judiciary of the Senate;
the Committee on Oversight of the House of Representatives; and
the Committee on the Judiciary of the House of Representatives.
